headline: Taiwan's AI-powered economy soars in the shadow of bubble fears and China threats
summary: In Taipei, real estate agent Jason Sung is betting that home prices around a high-tech industrial park in the northern part of Taiwan's capital will soon take flight – because of computer chip maker Nvidia.  The area is where Nvidia plans to build its new Taiwan headquarters as it rapidly expands on the island, set to surpass Apple to become the biggest customer of Taiwan semiconductor maker TSMC, the biggest contract manufacturer of the advanced chips needed for artificial intelligence.  Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang describes Taiwan as the “center of the world's computer ecosystem.”

content.title: Taiwan's AI-powered economy soars in the shadow of bubble fears and China threats
content.summary: In Taipei, real estate agent Jason Sung is betting that home prices around a high-tech industrial park in the northern part of Taiwan's capital will soon take flight – because of computer chip maker Nvidia.  The area is where Nvidia plans to build its new Taiwan headquarters as it rapidly expands on the island, set to surpass Apple to become the biggest customer of Taiwan semiconductor maker TSMC, the biggest contract manufacturer of the advanced chips needed for artificial intelligence.  Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang describes Taiwan as the “center of the world's computer ecosystem.”

headline: iPhone 17 Bucked China Mobile Lull in January, Counterpoint Says
summary: Every major Chinese mobile maker, from Huawei Technologies Co. to Xiaomi Corp., saw major declines in a market that was down 23% overall, Counterpoint’s researchers said, largely due to reduced subsidies and a shift in the timing of the Lunar New Year.  The iPhone 17 lineup, however, helped Apple to 8% growth, raising its share of the market to roughly a fifth, sharing the lead with Huawei.  Cupertino, California-based Apple has seen its flagship product stage a major comeback since the September introduction of new models.

content.title: iPhone 17 Bucked China Mobile Lull in January, Counterpoint Says
content.summary: Every major Chinese mobile maker, from Huawei Technologies Co. to Xiaomi Corp., saw major declines in a market that was down 23% overall, Counterpoint’s researchers said, largely due to reduced subsidies and a shift in the timing of the Lunar New Year.  The iPhone 17 lineup, however, helped Apple to 8% growth, raising its share of the market to roughly a fifth, sharing the lead with Huawei.  Cupertino, California-based Apple has seen its flagship product stage a major comeback since the September introduction of new models.

headline: Why the software sector meltdown might be overblown
summary: Software (IGV) stocks have been experiencing an artificial intelligence (AI)–fueled sell-off, but many investors say the market reaction is an overreaction. Yahoo Finance Technology Editor Dan Howley joins Asking for a Trend host Josh Lipton to delve further into the topic. He also explains the latest Apple (AAPL) headlines. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Asking for a Trend.

headline: Apple fends off 4G wireless patent lawsuit at third trial
summary: Apple won a defense verdict on Thursday in a lawsuit by intellectual-property management company Optis Wireless, which ‌had accused the tech giant of violating its patent rights in ‌4G wireless technology.  Optis had won verdicts of $506 million and $300 million against Apple in earlier trials in ​the long-running case in Marshall, Texas.  "We thank the jury for their time, and we’re pleased they rejected Optis’ false claims," an Apple spokesperson said.

content.title: Apple fends off 4G wireless patent lawsuit at third trial
content.summary: Apple won a defense verdict on Thursday in a lawsuit by intellectual-property management company Optis Wireless, which ‌had accused the tech giant of violating its patent rights in ‌4G wireless technology.  Optis had won verdicts of $506 million and $300 million against Apple in earlier trials in ​the long-running case in Marshall, Texas.  "We thank the jury for their time, and we’re pleased they rejected Optis’ false claims," an Apple spokesperson said.

thumbnail.caption: FILE PHOTO: Illustration shows Apple logo

headline: What Trump's DOJ shakeup could mean for Big Tech M&A
summary: Andrew Harnik/Getty Images Gail Slater, who has led the Department of Justice’s antitrust division for the last 11 months, is stepping down. She said she made the decision on her own, but multiple news outlets report that she was pushed out by President Donald Trump’s administration. Her ousting could mark a turning point: She has been a vocal advocate against tech monopolies and reportedly butted heads with Attorney General Pam Bondi and other high-ranking members of the administration, particu

content.title: What Trump's DOJ shakeup could mean for Big Tech M&A
content.summary: Andrew Harnik/Getty Images Gail Slater, who has led the Department of Justice’s antitrust division for the last 11 months, is stepping down. She said she made the decision on her own, but multiple news outlets report that she was pushed out by President Donald Trump’s administration. headline: Why Apple Stock Lost $200 Billion in Market Cap Today
summary: Apple shares fell 5% today, more than twice the decline of the tech-heavy Nasdaq composite as investors juggled a number of concerns at the iPhone maker.  The Federal Trade Commission issued a letter to Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook, warning that the company’s news product may violate federal law by promoting news articles from left-wing news outlets and suppressing articles from more conservative publications.  Apple's upgrade to its Siri virtual assistant might get pushed back, according to a report from Bloomberg.

content.title: Why Apple Stock Lost $200 Billion in Market Cap Today
content.summary: Apple shares fell 5% today, more than twice the decline of the tech-heavy Nasdaq composite as investors juggled a number of concerns at the iPhone maker.  The Federal Trade Commission issued a letter to Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook, warning that the company’s news product may violate federal law by promoting news articles from left-wing news outlets and suppressing articles from more conservative publications.  Apple's upgrade to its Siri virtual assistant might get pushed back, according to a report from Bloomberg.
